title: The American college graduate who has taken Irish football by storm
body_text:
THE CLICHÃ‰ when Irish clubs acquire foreign players is that they will need time to adapt and adjust to the rhythm and pace of the Premier Division.
However, this year, in both menâ€™s and womenâ€™s top flights, a pre-season signing from abroad sits at the top of the scoring charts.
In the menâ€™s game, New Zealand international Moses Dyer has been the leagueâ€™s most prolific player with nine goals since joining Galway in January.
For Shelbourne Women, Mackenzie Anthony has had a similarly positive impact.
The 23-year-old American has eight league goals from seven starts, leaving her joint top-scorer in the Premier Division alongside Athlone Townâ€™s New York-born forward Kelly Brady.
Brady recently pipped Anthony to Aprilâ€™s Player of the Month award, and it looks like it could be a race between the two Americans for the Golden Boot.
Anthonyâ€™s background is in college football in the US, while studying for a degree in advertising management.
Last autumn, she graduated from Michigan State University after two years there, having previously played three seasons at Baylor University in Texas.
Anthony subsequently went on trial with teams in the US, but had never been to Europe before and wanted to go â€œjust for the culture and the experienceâ€.
She considered Scandinavian countries but was keen to play somewhere where the main language was English.
Ireland had not been on her radar until Eoin Wearen got in touch last February.
The Shelbourne manager had previously coached in Anthonyâ€™s home city, Chicago. He had never met Anthony during that time, but did coach one of her best friends in football, Bella Najera.
Anthony also spoke with another US-born footballer, Maggie Pierce, who had a similar background in high-level college football and who spent two years at Shelbourne before departing at the end of 2024.
Three weeks after Wearen initially got in touch, Anthony received her holiday visa and was ready to go for the new season.
Mackenzie Anthony has been in flying form this season for Shels.
â€” League of Ireland (@LeagueofIreland) May 7, 2025
All her goals so far ğŸ”¥ pic.twitter.com/TUh7oSw8mx
The young striker has enjoyed her time in Ireland so far and finds it very â€œdifferentâ€ to her US football experience.
â€œItâ€™s very technical and very much touch play, quick passes, which I feel like, in the States, youâ€™re dribbling a lot more, I would say, especially up in the attack,â€ Anthony tells The 42.
â€œI thought it was interesting â€” everybody knows everybody in this league.
â€œPeople are dropping first names and it was funny because I didnâ€™t realise, everyoneâ€™s been playing against each other for years, or even with each other, which I guess it is how it is in the States, but not to that extent, where everybody knows everybodyâ€™s strengths, everybodyâ€™s weaknesses, in and out.â€
The Wheaton, Illinois native couldnâ€™t have asked for a much better start, averaging better than a goal a game in the league and coming off the bench to score an equaliser in their 1-1 draw with Bohemians in the All-Island Cup last weekend.
The US star also describes her adjustment off the pitch as â€œsmoother than I thought it was going to beâ€.
Based in Castleknock, she is roommates with Shelbourne goalkeeper Amanda McQuillan and recently got a Bernese Mountain Dog named Murphy to â€œhang out with all dayâ€.
Anthony has been able to get away for short trips to England and Spain during breaks in the season, and soon plans on visiting Italy with fellow American Shels player Gabby DelPico.
She compares this stint at Shelbourne to a â€œsemester abroadâ€ and finds it less exhausting compared to the lifestyle she was accustomed to in the States.
â€œI was going to get a part-time job at a coffee shop. I still might, but I just have so much time,â€ she adds.
â€œWhatâ€™s nice about this league, actually, is you do get so much time. Because I know in America, in college, your life revolves around soccer.
â€œSchool was part of it, but I feel like it was mainly just soccer that consumed you.
â€œSo itâ€™s been nice having more of a balance, getting to do so much more, and travel and explore.â€
The downside is that Anthony is playing in a part-time league where only some clubs pay travelling expenses.
â€œI would say I do wish it was more like full time, but it has given me the freedom to do more and just relax after five years of very intense soccer and it also gives my body a little break, Iâ€™d say, just not training as much â€” I feel like Iâ€™m able to recover better.
â€œBut in the future, I do think Iâ€™d want to go back to being more full-time. I could do that, play professionally, full-time.â€
In the US, Anthony would play twice a week and train four times, meaning she invariably got one day off a week.
â€œAnd even on that day off, we would have to be doing treatment, massages, still going in to lift, maybe, an optional lift and rehab, just injury stuff,â€ she explains.
Anthony believes this background is part of the reason why she has looked so impressive since moving to Shelbourne.
In the States, however, she did not always thrive in the demanding environment.
â€œItâ€™s easy to lose that love for the game when it has become such a monotonous thing.
â€œBut here Iâ€™m excited for training. Iâ€™m excited for the games. Itâ€™s not like I wasnâ€™t excited then, but I feel like I would get nervous before games. And here, I donâ€™t, which has been really freeing, I would say.â€
She is not anticipating a lengthy career in the game but hopes to compete at a high level for â€œat leastâ€ another four years.
â€œComing here, I was hoping Iâ€™d figure out more what Iâ€™d want to do once Iâ€™m done with playing,â€ she says. â€œBut I donâ€™t really know.â€
Anthony grew up competing in tennis and soccer, ultimately deciding to focus on the latter while in eighth grade.
â€œMy parents were like: â€˜Youâ€™ve got to pick a sport. Itâ€™s too much money to pay for two.â€™â€
At the age of just 14, Anthonyâ€™s footballing talent led to her being recruited by Baylor University.
It took the pressure off the final years of high school, knowing she had a college place secured.
â€œMy friends were all going through it when they were juniors and seniors. It was nice that I didnâ€™t have to worry about any of it.â€
While appreciative of the opportunities soccer has afforded her, Anthony admits there have been some dark moments too, such as when she missed an entire season after suffering an ACL injury in her second year of college.
â€œThere was a lot of being like: â€˜Do I even want to play anymore?â€™ Asking those questions. There was a point when my dad told me to quit because it got so stressful.
â€œI remember it was my fourth year, spring, and I was just really down and no confidence, nothing.
â€œAnd then I went and did Summer League [an amateur and semi-professional competition that US college players can avail of in the off-season], and I loved the game again. I was playing, and I was having fun with it. And you just, you remember [why I played in the first place]
â€œSo thereâ€™s going to be ups and downs â€” it [applies] everywhere. Just know, throughout your career, youâ€™re going to have so many ups and downs, and thatâ€™s just normal. Itâ€™s not normal to be only up â€” then somethingâ€™s wrong.â€
